title: Rearranging to General Form
text: The general form of a quadratic equation is written as ax²+bx+c. Can you rearrange the terms of $$g(x)=13+x^2-6x$$ to match this form?

title: Checking the Rearranged Equation
text: Once you have rearranged the equation, verify the order of the terms. Is it possible to write the equation with the x² term first, followed by the $$x$$ term, and finally the constant?

title: Rearranging Complete
text: Now, you should have $$g(x)=x^2-6x+13$$. This is the general form.

title: Finding Standard Form Using Completing the Square
text: To convert the equation into standard form, can you identify what terms are needed to complete the square for the equation $$g(x)=x^2-6x+13$$?

title: Completing the Square
text: What do you get when you complete the square on $$x^2-6x$$? How can this be written as a perfect square expression?

title: Writing the Expression as a Square
text: We know that $$x^2-6x$$ becomes $${\left(x-3\right)}^2$$ when a correction term is added. What is the correction term? How does this affect the constant in the equation?

title: Forming the Standard Form
text: Now include the correction term and finally subtract and add inside the equation. What expression do you get for g(x)?
